title: ISic000704. Funerary inscription of Gaius Iulius Eutychus
body:
1D(is) · m(anibus) · s(acrum) ·
2· C(aius) · Iulius · Eutych-
3·us · vixit · an(nos) · XXXX ·
4· uxor · b(ene) · mer(enti) · fec(it) ·

1DMS
2CIULIUSEUTYCH
3USVIXITANXXXX
4UXORBMERFEC

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from photograph

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Sacred to the spirits of the underworld. Gaius Iulius Eutychus lived for 40 years. His wife made this for a well deserving man.

Italian translation

Consacrato agli Dei Mani | Caius Iulius Eutychus | Visse per 40 anni | La moglie pose per (il marito) meritevole

commentary

Whether Gaius Iulius Eutychus was a freedman (former slave) or freeborn we cannot tell, but the absence of a father’s name perhaps suggests the former. The Greek name Εὐτύχης (‘good fortune’) is very common, in Sicily and across the Greek world. The inscription follows a very standard form for Latin epitaphs, although the use of interpuncts is excessive and is relatively unusual in appearing at the start and end of lines, including therefore mid-word/name (start of line 3).

bibliography

  • 1989.0341g https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283
  • Manganaro 1989 170 no.37 fig.39 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001831
  • 97 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000028
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.
